awd_titl_txt: Building a Learning Ecology to Increase STEM Participation Among Middle School Girls
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging in hands-on field experience, laboratory/project-based entrepreneurship tasks and mentorship experiences. 

The project is designed to increasie the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) participation of middle-school aged girls across various out-of-school (OST) programs in a midsized racially and socioeconomically diverse community. The project will research and develop a program, building on the existing Digital Youth Divas (DYD) program model, that focuses on coding, designing digital devices (e.g., sensors, devices sensitive to touch), and digital arts and design and that will intentionally address areas that are of interest to girls. The project will collaborate with EvanSTEM, a collaborative of Evanston, Illinois, community organizations that offer STEM education activities, to create a community-led initiative learning initiative that combines STEM with the arts (STEAM). The project STEAM ecosystem will focus on three components: the DYD city collective that consists of out-of-school (OST) organizations that provide STEM programming for girls; DYD Caring Adult Network (a community of parents focused on supporting STEM activities among girls); and the Divas Circle (a community of 5-8th grade girls from across Evanston who participate in DYD affiliated programming and events). This project leverages collaboration with a local community of OST providers, parents, and educators to create a system of STEM learning opportunities, social supports and technical infrastructure.

The project will investigate several key research questions: 

(1)	How can middle school girls better connect with STEM learning opportunities and how can organizations more effectively coordinate their offerings and connect them to girls?
(2)	What factors contribute to the creation of a local STEM ecosystem that engages and sustains girls' STEM interest and participation?
(3)	How can parents (or other caregivers) be engaged in supporting girls' participation in STEM and what impact does their involvement have?
(4)	What impact does participation have on family STEM identity and on girls' long term participation and interest in STEM activities and programs?

The project will use a variety of research methods and date collection including: school district data such as student course registrations; youth surveys assessing participation levels, interest, and impacts; online participation data that will reveal levels and patterns of involvement; interviews with students, parents, and providers; and case study data of a sample of participating families.  The project will share research findings widely with the educational research community through academic venues such as professional conferences and journals and with practitioners through professional development workshops and by sharing resource materials and curriculum on the www.digitalyouthnetwork.org/divas website.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
This Collaborative ITEST Strategies project sought to articular the structures and practices necessary to empower community stakeholders to operate their own hyperlocal middle school girls STEAM program powered by the community's provider network. Our project focused on increasing the STEM participation of middle-school-aged girls in STEM activities by strengthening three core components of the Digital Youth Divas model: the DYD Collective, the Caring Adult Network (CAN), and the Divas Circle. The Collective, a network of community-based out-of-school (OST) STEAM providers including parks, libraries, YMCA, university researcher-led STEM projects, and local community-led organizations partnered with the DePaul and Northwestern research and design teams to understand and adapt their recruitment and instructional practices better to engage girls and their families in STEM programming. Through our work, we iterated on our system design to answer the following questions:

  • How can we better connect STEM learning opportunities for middle school girls across the ecosystem?
  • How do we facilitate the creation of local OST STEM providers that engage and sustain girls' participation?
  • What is the impact of engaging parents in a community to support girls' participation in STEM?
  • What impact does DYD CAN have on family STEM identities and STEM efficacy?
  • By participating in DYD Circle, what impacts girls' long-term participation and interest in STEM activities and programming?

Through iterative cycles of design, reflection, and iteration, our work has achieved the below outcomes that have established DYD as a core parent for the Evanston learning ecosystem while also resulting in a set of programming models that can support uptake in other communities.

Integrating Programming with Collective Partners

  • We have strengthened our collective partnerships with critical local community organizations and associations in Evanston (EvanSTEM, YMCA McGaw, the Evanston Public Library, Division of Youth and Young Adults, and Parks and Recreation) and Chicago (Chicago Park District, Chicago Public Schools, and the Chicago Housing Authority).
  • In partnership with the Evanston Parks & Recreation Department, we established the newly renovated community center as a daily home base for Divas youth and family programming. Additionally, as reliable buses for after-school programs have been a persistent problem across Evanston neighborhoods, to facilitate participation, we established a partnership with the Parks Department buses to provide transportation from schools to the community center. 
  • In partnership with the Evanston Public Library teen programs, offered quarterly family STEM for Divas families to engage in STEM challenges together.

Established a Caring Adult Network

  • Through this grant, CAN evolved from a PI lead initiative into a parent-led initiative by forming a dedicated advisory board of parents. In addition, the advisory board partnered in opening CAN to community members dedicated to cultivating meaningful OST STEAM opportunities for all youth in the community. 

Expanded Divas Circle Programming

  • Expanded programming to include Divas Destinations, STEM field trips throughout Illinois and surrounding states to showcase the many ways STEM/STEAM shows up in the world and to expose the youth participants to potential careers and areas of exploration. 

Impact of DYD on Mentor Workforce

  • A unique aspect of the DYD model is the focus on training college-going students as near-peer mentors to lead programming in their home communities. An outcome of this grant is establishing a DYD certification program that engages community college students in an intentionally created training sequence that includes Divas core STEAM content, roles for supporting learners, and socioemotional learning. Mentors who complete the training are qualified for hiring to lead Divas programming in partner locations across the city.

Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic

  • The DYD Program held youth programming successfully before and throughout the pandemic because we worked with families to adapt our model in response to the changing conditions. The program design changed throughout the 3-year project due to the impacts of the pandemic. In the first grant year, youth programming was held on Saturdays until March 2020. Virtual meetings were held on Saturday mornings through May 2021, with additional virtual social events one to two nights a week from October 2020-May to 2021. In October 2021, Divas programming shifted back to in-person sessions after school twice a week, with partner programming three days a week. This new after-school schedule also included bussing support from participants' schools to the community center location.

In summary, a contribution of this project is a STEM learning ecosystem exemplar that models how to build both girls' and caring adults' networks to understand better how to work with community partners to create more engaging STEM programming.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Nichole Pinkard
por.por_txt_cntn:
This Collaborative ITEST Strategies project sought to articular the structures and practices necessary to empower community stakeholders to operate their own hyperlocal middle school girls STEAM program powered by the community's provider network. Our project focused on increasing the STEM participation of middle-school-aged girls in STEM activities by strengthening three core components of the Digital Youth Divas model: the DYD Collective, the Caring Adult Network (CAN), and the Divas Circle. The Collective, a network of community-based out-of-school (OST) STEAM providers including parks, libraries, YMCA, university researcher-led STEM projects, and local community-led organizations partnered with the DePaul and Northwestern research and design teams to understand and adapt their recruitment and instructional practices better to engage girls and their families in STEM programming. Through our work, we iterated on our system design to answer the following questions:

How can we better connect STEM learning opportunities for middle school girls across the ecosystem?
How do we facilitate the creation of local OST STEM providers that engage and sustain girls' participation?
What is the impact of engaging parents in a community to support girls' participation in STEM?


What impact does DYD CAN have on family STEM identities and STEM efficacy?


By participating in DYD Circle, what impacts girls' long-term participation and interest in STEM activities and programming?


Through iterative cycles of design, reflection, and iteration, our work has achieved the below outcomes that have established DYD as a core parent for the Evanston learning ecosystem while also resulting in a set of programming models that can support uptake in other communities.

Integrating Programming with Collective Partners

We have strengthened our collective partnerships with critical local community organizations and associations in Evanston (EvanSTEM, YMCA McGaw, the Evanston Public Library, Division of Youth and Young Adults, and Parks and Recreation) and Chicago (Chicago Park District, Chicago Public Schools, and the Chicago Housing Authority).
In partnership with the Evanston Parks & Recreation Department, we established the newly renovated community center as a daily home base for Divas youth and family programming. Additionally, as reliable buses for after-school programs have been a persistent problem across Evanston neighborhoods, to facilitate participation, we established a partnership with the Parks Department buses to provide transportation from schools to the community center. 
In partnership with the Evanston Public Library teen programs, offered quarterly family STEM for Divas families to engage in STEM challenges together.


Established a Caring Adult Network

Through this grant, CAN evolved from a PI lead initiative into a parent-led initiative by forming a dedicated advisory board of parents. In addition, the advisory board partnered in opening CAN to community members dedicated to cultivating meaningful OST STEAM opportunities for all youth in the community. 


Expanded Divas Circle Programming

Expanded programming to include Divas Destinations, STEM field trips throughout Illinois and surrounding states to showcase the many ways STEM/STEAM shows up in the world and to expose the youth participants to potential careers and areas of exploration. 


Impact of DYD on Mentor Workforce

A unique aspect of the DYD model is the focus on training college-going students as near-peer mentors to lead programming in their home communities. An outcome of this grant is establishing a DYD certification program that engages community college students in an intentionally created training sequence that includes Divas core STEAM content, roles for supporting learners, and socioemotional learning. Mentors who complete the training are qualified for hiring to lead Divas programming in partner locations across the city.


Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic

The DYD Program held youth programming successfully before and throughout the pandemic because we worked with families to adapt our model in response to the changing conditions. The program design changed throughout the 3-year project due to the impacts of the pandemic. In the first grant year, youth programming was held on Saturdays until March 2020. Virtual meetings were held on Saturday mornings through May 2021, with additional virtual social events one to two nights a week from October 2020-May to 2021. In October 2021, Divas programming shifted back to in-person sessions after school twice a week, with partner programming three days a week. This new after-school schedule also included bussing support from participants' schools to the community center location.


In summary, a contribution of this project is a STEM learning ecosystem exemplar that models how to build both girls' and caring adults' networks to understand better how to work with community partners to create more engaging STEM programming.
